When a burst of blue light occurs, it is always about electricity, when a green light appears, it is always about magnetism. When blue appears, which is characteristic of electricity in the background of its cause is always a kind of magnetic phenomenon, when green appears, which is characteristic of magnetism in the background of its cause is always electricity. These are phenomena that people periodically encounter in everyday life. But there is a difference between “flowing” fluid electricity and static electricity, when it comes to static electricity, the lightning that occurs is always white or pale yellow. These natural colors in a normal environment in a space rich in a standard amount of oxygen change when they are exposed to various gases in the space, which means that the amount of oxygen affects the colors and their shades ..

35mm film is held onto the spool with a short piece of adhesive tape looped around the spool.  In the darkroom, instead of snipping the film from the spool, if the tape was unpeeled from the film, you could see the blue sparks.  When the film was processed, you could see the dark spots in the emulsion that represented the flashes of light.  You could also get a feeling for how quickly the adhesive tape was unpeeled, lots of light for a quick unpeeling, or very little light if slowly unpeeled, not that that information is likely to be important, just interesting to get a glimpse into what took place in that darkroom many years prior.

It's probably due to the change in capacitance as you separate the Band-Aid wrappers or tape from the roll that channels the charge along the glue line so that the charge overcomes the dielectric strength of the air in the vicinity of the glue line.

Basic capacitance formulas are based on the area of the plates, plate size, and dielectric between them. It assumes that the plates are always parallel to each other. Peeling the tape from a roll, or unwrapping Band-Aids destroys the parallel plate assumption thus changing the capacitance between them allowing for the discharge phenomena observed.

The effect seems most pronounced only where the package adhesive is. On Scotch Tape it would be a continuous line. Makes me wonder if the effect isn't moderated specifically by the type of glue used. I believe Scotch Tape is thin film acetate.

why x-rays? because there is less air, right? the charges need air to jump from one to the other, it can't jump a vacuum, so it needs the air to get the electrons from one side, if there is less air, the charges build up more, so the excitation should be greater.

if this is the case, then increasing the air, should produce a weaker effect, since normal air produces a blue light, and decreasing the air pressure results in an x-ray light, it would stand to reason increasing the air pressure should result in a light with a lower frequency...more towards the red. and obviously using an air which ionizes easier should also produce a light more towards the red (as seen in neon or other noble gases) and using an air which ionizes LESS easily should produce a light more towards the x-ray.

it's kinda like putting gunpowder in a container...put it in cardboard get a firecracker, put it in a steel pipe get a pipe bomb. even if it's the same amount of gunpowder (be a very BIG firecracker...like one of those mortar shells...but still not as destructive as a pipe bomb with the same amount of gunpowder)

The reason you get x-rays in a vacuum is that you do not have a gas as a transfer vector for the charge that is building up, so the charge gets much higher before it releases directly across the adhesive contact point, so the energy is much higher for each electron transfer, producing photons of much higher frequency. Same happens with lightning. I will add that if a bandage does not do this, you should probably use a different brand on a wound.

I've long known about triboluminescence when you crunch up a Winter-o-green Lifesaver and I've seen it myself.
My understanding is that it's a complicated process. When you crush the life saver it distorts xylenol sugar crystals and they give off births of ultraviolet light. The ultraviolet light light then strikes other components in the lifesaver causing them to fluoresce in visible light.
They have since changed the formula and they no longer spark.
But I also noticed triboluminescence in a plastic bottle.
It was some kind of fruit punch or fruit drink and I was drinking it right before I went to bed. The lights were out and I decided to finish the bottle and when did so I crushed it. I could see little green flashes of light as I crushed it.
I wiggled the bottle back and forth and made it do it again and again. I was able to notice that the plastic bottle was actually two layers laminated together. And by crushing the bottle the to layers separated this is what caused the spark.

If you measure each door then the wave function collapses which means that you see the particle at a specific location. Also the interference pattern disappears. Here is why this makes no sense:
You could place only one measuring device at door 1
Particle goes through door 2
The measuring device didn't interfere with the particle in any way. No electromagnetic communication took place between the measuring device and the particle.
YET the wave function still collapsed.

Doesn't this prove that it is the knowledge about the information associated with the particle and not the physical interaction of the sensor with the particle that is causing the collapse of the wave function? What collapses the wave function if the sensor at door 1 never measures the particle at door 2?

If so then is quantum mechanics a scientific theory which is not describing the physical interaction of physical objects which have physical properties but instead is describing information in a quantum system?

Love you, love your content. But just to nit pic a pet peeve of mine.
Camera gain or “ISO” Isn’t a acronym, it’s not I.S.O. so you don’t pronounce it “Eye, Ess, Oh”
It’s from the Greek “ISOS” (which means equal)
So it can be pronounced “EyeSo” Or “eeso” as a single word.
It’s a understandable mistake as they insist on writing it with capitals. And the company initials is IOS (just to further add to the confusion)
But if you go to the inventors of ISO (International Organization for Standardization) they explain all this there.
